repnme.cdata!:
Timor-Leste - First, Second, and Third
            Community Empowerment and Local Governance Projects; and the
            First and Second Agricultural Rehabilitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Community and Local Governance
            Project (CEP I), the Second Community Empowerment Project
            (CEP II), and the Third Community Empowerment and Local
            Governance Project (CEP III) had the following ratings:
            unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely sustainability, modest
            institutional development impact, unsatisfactory Bank
            performance, and not rated (CEP I), satisfactory (CEP II),
            and satisfactory (CEP III) Grantee performance.  The
            Agricultural Rehabilitation Project had the following
            ratings: moderately satisfactory outcome, unlikely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impact,
            satisfactory Bank performance, and not rated Grantee
            performance.  The Second Agricultural Rehabilitation Project
            had the following ratings: moderately unsatisfactory
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, modest institutional
            development impact, unsatisfactory Bank performance, and
            satisfactory Grantee performance. Experience with these
            projects highlights the following lessons: 1) With its
            global outreach and the expertise and experience of its
            staff the Bank is well positioned to make a substantial
            contribution to post-conflict reconstruction and
            development.  However, the experience of the three community
            empowerment and the two agriculture rehabilitation projects
            shows that careful thought to suitability of design and
            strategies to country conditions is paramount, especially
            where country capacity is weak; 2) even in the case of
            post-conflict Timor-Leste, where sophisticated monitoring
            and evaluation was impractical, there was a need to have a
            system to track project inputs, outputs, and outcomes and
            provide information about the adaptations needed in project
            design to ensure that the project objectives and activities
            are in keeping with the emerging institutional context and
            the absorptive capacity of the country; 3) particularly in
            post-conflict environments, an approach to capacity building
            that considers the underlying capacity in the country as
            well as how it would be promoted by the various donors is
            critical; and 4) the experience of Timor-Leste highlights
            the critical importance of coordinating multi-agency
            reconstruction efforts more effectively in a newly
            independent post-conflict country.

2210548.trustfund:
TF038992-EAST TIMOR - AGRICULTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECTS I & II SPN,TF023762-TFET - IBRD OPERATING COSTS
            ASSOCIATED WITH THE TRUST FUND FOR EAST TIM,TF040779-EAST TIMOR - AGRICULTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF040747-EAST TIMOR: AGRIC
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF040620-EAST TIMOR - AGRIC. REHAB
            PROJ/SECOND SMALL ENTERPRISE PROJECT,TF023824-TFET - AGRICULTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The violence of 1999 destroyed much of
            east Timor's rural sector, with farms destroyed,
            processing machinery smashed, tools stolen, and farm animals
            killed. Through the first agriculture rehabilitation
            project, the World Bank-administered trust fund for east
            Timor has helped communities get farm animals and farm
            tools, repaired small irrigation schemes and roads, and
            trained agriculture staff. A second phase of this
            initiative, approved in June 2001, aims to build on the
            successful community-based activities of the first project
            by improving food security for farm families and increasing
            agricultural production. More than a thousand radios have
            been given away to people living in 14 separate communities
            to ensure they can stay in touch with the issues facing
            their new nation.

5086861.trustfund:
TF040747-EAST TIMOR: AGRIC
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF023824-TFET - AGRICULTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF023762-TFET - IBRD OPERATING COSTS
            ASSOCIATED WITH THE TRUST FUND FOR EAST TIM,TF038992-EAST TIMOR - AGRICULTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECTS I & II SPN,TF040620-EAST TIMOR - AGRIC. REHAB
            PROJ/SECOND SMALL ENTERPRISE PROJECT,TF040779-EAST TIMOR - AGRICULTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agriculture Rehabilitation Project
            is an emergency recovery project which aims to improve food
            security of selected poor households, and increase
            agricultural production in selected project areas and
            promote rural growth. Because the trust fund for East Timor
            does not have all the necessary project funding at this
            stage, project financing will be divided into two grants.
            The first grant finance priority activities to be carried
            out during the initial 12 months of the project. The
            components that will be financed under this grant include:
            a) priority productive asset restoration which will conduct
            national vaccination campaigns to immunize cattle, small
            ruminants, and pigs, etc; b) irrigation and rural
            infrastructure studies, rehabilitation, and maintenance,
            which will cover community rehabilitation and maintenance of
            irrigation infrastructure and agriculture access roads,
            procurement of equipment, and feasibility and engineering
            studies to identify feasible irrigation improvements and
            selecting the schemes where rehabilitation would be most
            viable; and c) pilot agriculture services centers, to
            provide farming communities with farm inputs, mechanization
            services, etc;. The second grant will finance the remaining
            project activities which may have started during the first
            grant, but would need to continue until the project closes.
            Besides the second grant will also finance the establishment
            of a project management unit.
